[h1]10/10[/h1]
[list] 
    [*]For Everyone: Recommended. This is an easy mainstream recommendation. Masterpiece of a game. 
[/list]

[url=https://martopad.medium.com/bioshock-infinite-review-52f37914bf1a]For Full Review; as my review exceeds Steam's charater limit[/url]

Bioshock Infinite will always be the game that Iâ€™m scared of playing but will begrudgingly continue to finish because the story is so good. For a game that gave me difficulty in sleeping. Even after finishing the game, I was watching videos online about its lore, and explanation pieces. 

[h1]THEREâ€™S ALWAYS A MAN WHO REVIEWS[/h1]
For a game that gave me nightmares for a week or two. Why buy it? It was poor research on my part. I mainly buy games on steam, and Bioshock Infinite is cheap during sales. And I say hey since it's cheap and itâ€™s a game highly regarded as a masterpiece why not give it a shot? ...

[h1]THEREâ€™S ALWAYS EXPECTATIONS[/h1]
In this game, you are Booker Dewitt, who is on a mission to Columbia. A city in the sky. This is set in 1912, with some trappings of real life. It prefaces itself to a scenario like Bioshock 1; what if there was a person who aimed to make a city in the sky.  
Let me tell you, Bioshock Infiniteâ€™s graphics still amazed me in 2020. Its art-style holds up even after 7 years. Not to mention it runs well on my gaming rig (i7 8650U and a 2070S) considering I have an Ultrabook CPU. They went with this art style that mashes realism with a comic-book type of style. Iâ€™m glad they went with this because it doesnâ€™t look dated in 2020. 
The moment you get introduced to Columbia; you will enjoy every moment of it. They sell the â€œcity floating in the skyâ€ well. From captivating visuals like architecture, famous American figures, clouds that obscure the distant floating cities, and cities slightly swaying left and right. To great sound effects like the loud roaring of floating machinery, crowd murmurings, crowd activity, bells tolling from afar, and old-school-style music being played from their radios. Currently, as Iâ€™m writing this, Iâ€™m listening/watching to ambient Bioshock Infinite videos on YouTube, because of how much content there is from just sitting in a corner and let the world play its thing. How I wish they would release a patch that would let players just explore the levels with NPCs roaming around without combat. It's so good. 

[h1]SHOOT, SHOCK, and PUNCH![/h1]
As much I want to gush about the gameâ€™s visuals, sound effects, and music. This is only part of the game. Bioshock Infiniteâ€™s mechanics are also great. 
As with any Bioshock games, there is a mix here of both guns and Vigors (same with plasmids in Bioshock games). The gun selection is as expected. From your normal range of pistols to rifles. The game gives you enough variety to tackle enemies, which is shooting them to the face. Nothing mind-blowing here.
Unlike guns, the Vigor selection provides many ways to combat enemies. From the classic â€œShock Jockeyâ€ (Electro Bolt) to â€œReturn to Senderâ€ (which absorbs incoming damage and hurls it back to enemies). With the variety, I was able to find the combo Iâ€™m comfortable with; a Sniper rifle with Shock Jockey and Possession (which temporarily controls enemies and turn them on your side). 
But the game will throw you in situations wherein you must try and change your strategy. ...
In addition to your arsenal, there is now a new weapon/exploration tool, called the Sky-Hook. It adds a new dynamic to combat and lore-wise it makes sense. ...
Among the new features that this game has introduced. Your partner, Elizabeth is the best new feature they have implemented. Oh man, she was a big help helping me getting through this game. To whoever programmed her behavior you guys deserve a raise! They programmed her with so much personality, I can see why the steam community page is still brimming with Elizabeth's content. Once you get to be her partner, she will walk beside you as you explore and do combat. 
During exploration sequences you will see her interacting with the environment; Sitting on benches, looking at windows, throwing rocks at the beach, and many more. She will also ask/talk to you when you do something; going into female bathrooms, exploring objects, looking at decorations, and many more. She is also well-animated showing emotion well. One more thing that she does during exploration sequences is she will tell you where some items are by calling your attention, and she will also find and give some currency for you. 
...
The thing with Elizabeth that amazes me is they managed to make an AI partner that is not cumbersome, filled with personality and helps (Iâ€™m looking at you Wolfenstein: Young Blood). I would go on a limb and say that even if she didnâ€™t have any combat-related functionality, I will still give a huge positive here. Because I liked her not because she gives me combat advantage, but because she has personality. I immediately got attached to her and was constantly looking at her behavior during exploration sequences. She made my experience in this game more beautiful. 

[h1]THE STORY THAT MADE MY JAW DROP[/h1]
In my opinion, the most welcomed feature that Bioshock Infinite inherited from its predecessors is its exploration-based storytelling and exploration in general. Bioshock Infinite will reward you by exploring its world. It will reward you by giving you in game materials like ammo, and currency. But the most important one is the Voxophones. Voxophones are the same as audio recordings.
Same with other Bioshock games, Bioshock Infinite allows you to understand more of whatâ€™s happening by finding these Voxophones. I would compare the experience here to how raytracing makes everything more beautiful. A game like Battlefield V already looks beautiful, but when raytracing is enabled it looks even better. Voxophones contextualizes your perspective while playing the game, the story is great, but these audio logs make it perfect. 
As I collected Voxophones, there were â€œOHHHH SHIT!â€, and â€œSO THATâ€™S WHY!â€ moments. It's so refreshing to have these moments sprinkled throughout the game. There was one instance wherein a new character is introduced, and I donâ€™t have a clue of who this person is. As the game progressed, I collected Voxophones that introduced who this character is and what happened. The recordings showed humanity in these people, their motivation, their thoughts. It showed a glimpse of the why in their actions. Which enriches the cutscenes and set pieces more. The voice work in this is amazing, from minor rants to grand statements. They convey emotion in their voice for both when you see the characters, and in Voxophones.

[h1]THEREâ€™S ALWAYS A VERDICT[/h1]
Bioshock Infinite is a game that has amazing storytelling, great combat, and rewarding exploration. I was emotionally invested through its up and downs. Even when the game is over, I was thinking about it. I can see this already being considered a gaming classic, and in 2020 still a masterpiece of a game. The horror aspect of the game may be a possible deterrent but I tell you, experiencing this game was worth it.

This game seems to be perceived as some sort of classic, and in some ways I can see why. The story is leagues beyond gaming's usual standards, the world building and characters are great, and the maps are just delightful. However, it was a close call deciding to recommend this one, mostly because while all those things are great, the core gameplay is combat, and the design of that element is terrible. All the usual suspects that make modern shooters insipid make an appearance: impressively uninspired weapon design, regenerating health, slow movement speed, and near universal use of hitscan weapons among enemies. The big upsides of the story and the low price tag are enough to outweigh this and you'll probably have a good time on your first playthrough. The fact that the game succeeds despite the combat is a testament to how well done the other elements are.
The best of the three games, amazing!
From the bottom of the seas (Bioshock 1 and 2) to the sky. It still gives me much of a joy to play. A very good game.

It is so beautiful, the atmosphere, different maps, everything is so beautiful. The story is great, it's a little more colorful than the other BioShock games but BioShock Infinite still has a creepy atmosphere to it. If you haven't played the other two games, don't worry. There is only one thing at the end that would make more sense if you played BioShock 1 first. My advice is stop overthinking and just buy it. It has a good amount of fighting, the story is great and if you like looting you'll love this game.

I loved the first Bioshock, liked the second one, could not stand Infinite. Gameplay was never Bioshockâ€™s selling point, but this one really boils it down to moving from one area to the next and killing lackluster enemies with low AI. Gameplay is repetitive, weapons are uninteresting. Vigors feel out of place and you donâ€™t really need to bother with them given the gameâ€™s ridiculously easy difficulty. There is almost zero punishment for death. And the lootingâ€¦ Instead of enjoying the beautiful graphics, the game expects you to walk to every corner in every area in order to loot cash from garbage bins and drawers. I did not have patience to finish the game, so maybe it was the story that made many critics regard this as GOTY for 2013. I cannot comment on the story, but in terms of gameplay, BioShock Inifinite is a tedious game.
